name: phosphane production | phosphane | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/475/documentation

This dataset represents the production of phosphane by means of the hydration of phosphorus. Phosphane is a colorless, very poisonous gas whith an intense and penetrating odor.;It is mostly used captively as a starting material in the production of organophosphorus compounds, mainly by addition of aldehydes or alkenes to the P–H bonds. Phosphane is also used for pest control where foodstuffs and animal feeds are stored. Almost all dry products of this type are suitable for gassing with phosphane without any harmful effects on properties such as smell, taste, and appearance. The main area of use is in gassing grain silos. In the semiconductor industry, specially purified phosphane (arsine-free in particular) is used as a dopant.;Due to a lack of industrial data, this dataset is based on stoechiometric calculations and approximations based on data from a large chemical plant (Gendorf 2016).;References:;Sutter, J. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Highly Pure Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 19. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.;Bettermann, G., Krause, W., Riess, G. and Hofmann, T. 2000. Phosphorus Compounds, Inorganic. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.;Gendorf (2016) Umwelterklärung 2015, Werk Gendorf Industriepark, www.gendorf.de.

From the reception of phosphorus, pure water and sodium hydroxide at the factory gate.

This activity ends with the production of phosphane including the consumption of raw materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions. Since phosphane is a very poisonous gas, the whole system is a closed loop. Therefore no emissions to air are considered.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/202:Manufacture of other chemical products/2021:Manufacture of pesticides and other agrochemical products

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Time of publications. Some values are based on data published by the Gendorf factory that were collected between 2011 and 2015. The time period has been adjusted accordingly. For more details, see the comments of the exchanges.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for the world. Some values are based on data from a large chemical factory located in Germany. These are assumed to be valid for this geography.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Phosphane can be synthesized by a number of different reactions. On the laboratory scale, it may be prepared simply by the hydrolysis of metal phosphides or phosphonium salts. The two most common industrial methods are based on disproportionation reactions of elemental phosphorus catalyzed by alkalies or acids. A well-known example is the reaction of white phosphorus with sodium hydroxide solution, which is used to produce both phosphane and sodium hypophosphite, NaH2PO2 (sodium phosphinite).;In sodium hypophosphite production plants, the phosphane byproduct is usually burnt off. In the presence of alcohols, the reaction may be controlled such that the product formed in addition to phosphane is almost entirely sodium phosphite Na2HPO3. At the same time, the maximum yield based on the amount of phosphorus used increases from 25 % to 50 %. ;In acid-catalyzed disproportionation, white phosphorus is converted into phosphane and phosphoric acid at ca. 280 °C, red phosphorus being formed as an intermediate.;This reaction gives the highest yield of PH3 based on the amount of phosphorus used (theoretical yield 62.5 % for phosphane and 37.5 % for phosphoric acid). Due to the high reaction temperature and the corrosiveness of the medium, the reactor must be made of graphite.;The phosphoric acid is then neutralized with sodium hydroxide.;In this dataset, the production of phosphane by means of the hydration of phosphorus is considered.;References:;Svara, J., Weferling, N.: Phosphorus compounds, organic. Published online: 2000. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/emrw/9783527306732/home
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data based on literature and stoichiometric calculations. Some values are calculated based on data from a large chemical factory located in Germany. For more details, see the comments of the exchanges.

exchanges.description:
Phosphane is is a colorless, very poisonous gas whith an intense and penetrating odor. The odor threshold is extremely dependent on the purity of the gas. High-purity PH3 (5 N), as used in the semiconductor industry, is detectable by smell only when the concentration is at a dangerously toxic level (> 1000 ppm), but when PH3 is produced by the hydrolysis of AlP or Mg3P2, it can be detected even at ca. 20 ppb. Phosphane is very toxic. The LC50 and LD50 values show that the acute toxicity decreases with increasing molecular mass. Above 375 °C, phosphine decomposes into the elements. Phosphine - air mixtures are explosive over a wide range. The lower explosion limit is 1.6%, and the upper limit is close to 100 %. Pure phosphine should presumably therefore be regarded as spontaneously flammable like phosphine that contains P2H4 as an impurity. With strong acids, phosphine forms phosphonium salts; e.g., with hydrogen iodide, phosphonium iodide, PH4I, is formed, from which pure phosphine may be liberated by adding water or solutions of alkalimetal hydroxides.

The phosphane is mostly used captively as a starting material in the production of organophosphorus compounds, mainly by addition of aldehydes or alkenes to the P-H bonds. Phosphine is also used for pest control where foodstuffs and animal feeds are stored. Almost all dry products of this type are suitable for gassing with phosphane without any harmful effects on such properties as smell, taste, and appearance. The main area of use is in gassing grain silos. In the semiconductor industry, specially purified phosphane (arsine-free in particular) is used as a dopant.

exchanges.description: Stoechiometric calculation. The sodium phosphate from the phosphoric acid neutralization is assumed to leave the production process with the wastewater. Further it is assumed that this wastewater is treated in a internal wastewater plant. The removal efficiency for phosphate is assumed with 51.8%. The removed phosphate is accounted as inert waste. The remaining phosphorus (5% of the input) and the removed phosphate are assumed to be disposed as inert waste.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of river water in the years 2015-2019 was 22000820 t per year. However, since the cooling water is modelled as an input, the amount of river water was adjusted to avoid double counting. 55% of the input amount of cooling water was deducted from the amount of river water, as that is the share of river water versus well water. This equals 0.00096543 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. To determine the emissions of water to air, the difference of all water inputs (from river, well, tap water and cooling) and outputs (wastewater, emissions to water) was calculated. The average ouput of water to air in the years 2015-2019 was 3620444 m3 per year. This equals 0.00147 m3/kg chemical produced. For more information on the other water exchanges please consult the respective exchange comment.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The amount of water released back to the environment consists of the sum of the amount of process water treated in the internal WWTP that is then released back to the environment and the amount of cooling water released back to the environment. The average ouput of  the internal WWTP in the years 2015-2019 was 2628800 m3 and that of cooling water released back to the environment was 34408800 m3. This gives a yearly average of 37037600 m3 emissions of water to water. This equals 0.01504 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average amount of cooling water released in the years 2015-2019 was 34408800 t per year. It was assumed that 5% of the cooling water was emitted to air during its use, therefore, to calculate the input of cooling water, the output value reported by GENDORF was scaled up by the factor 1/0.95. This equals 0.014707 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average consumption of well water in the years 2015-2019 was 18607480 t per year. However, since the cooling water is modelled as an input, the amount of well water was adjusted to avoid double counting. 45% of the input amount of cooling water was deducted from the amount of well water, as that is the share of well water versus river water. This equals 0.00081652 m3/kg chemical produced.

References:
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

flow.name: Water, well, in ground
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.
